author: Brigid Glanville
title: Forced council amalgamations could be scrapped in NSW Government backflip - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)

organizations.name: orange to the shooters and fishers party

text:
In what would be Ms Berejiklian's first major policy departure from her predecessor Mike Baird, the ABC understands the Premier could abandon the controversial policy. 
Plebiscites could be used to "unmerge" councils that have already been amalgamated. 
The Government has already created 20 new councils, but 11 are still in the pipeline. 
In January, NSW National Party leader John Barilaro issued an ultimatum to Ms Berejiklian that his party would no longer be forcing local government mergers. 
Several municipalities have taken the matter to court, with Woollahra Council, in Sydney's east, leading the fight. 
Last month, the council lodged a High Court appeal over a blueprint that would see it merge with the cities of Randwick and Waverly. Government 'listened to community' 
Local Government NSW (LGNSW) president Keith Rhoades welcomed the policy shift, saying the Berejiklian Government had listened to the community. 
"LGNSW has spent a lot of today in meetings with Deputy Premier John Barilaro and the newly installed Local Government Minister Gabrielle Upton," Cr Rhoades said. 
"It would be inappropriate to reveal the content of those discussions, but I can certainly say they were both constructive and productive." 
The policy is deeply unpopular in regional areas, and was seen as a major reason behind the Nationals losing the seat of Orange to the Shooters and Fishers Party in a by-election late last year. 
The Nationals suffered a swing of more than 20 per cent against them. 
There are more by-elections on the horizon with Government MPs Mr Baird and Jillian Skinner retiring. 
The proposed merger between North Sydney, Mosman and Willoughby, is a controversial issue in Ms Skinner's seat of North Shore. 
Meanwhile, in Mr Baird's seat of Manly, opponents of the policy have vowed to unseat the Liberal Party.
